Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Analysis of Mutants Identified in Screens for Suppressors or Enhancers of a Red Light Hypersensitive E3 Ubiquitin-Ligase Mutant
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to perceive and respond to light is vital to plant growth and development. Previous work by the Principal Investigator (PI) has identified and characterized two genes (LRB1 and LRB2) in the model flowering plant Arabidopsis thaliana that regulate responses to red wavelength light. Mutant plants with disruptions of these two genes are, among other things, more shade tolerant. The PI has used these mutants as a basis for novel genetic screens intended to identify additional genes that have roles in light perception and response. This project will use a variety of standard molecular, genetic, and biochemical approaches to study these genes.

By identifying and characterizing genes which had not been previously implicated in light responses, this project will provide new insights into the mechanisms by which plants respond to their light environment. Shade responses are important in agriculture, as shading can reduce agronomic performance by increasing lodging (falling over), decreasing yield, and reducing plant defenses to pathogens and pests, therefore the information obtained in this project may help guide future work on light responses in crop plants. Also, the majority of work in this project will be conducted by undergraduate students at the University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire (a four-year public comprehensive university), significantly enhancing their education and making them more competitive and better prepared as they enter graduate/professional school or the workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded work to study red and far-red light light perception in the plant Arabidopsis thaliana. This work used genetic screens to identify multiple mutations in the gene encoding the major red-light photoreceptor in plants that reduced or enhanced the activity of the photoreceptor. These mutations will give insight into the structure/function of the photoreceptor. The enhancer mutants are particularly intriguing, as only one mutation which increases activity of the photoreceptor has been previously reported in the literature. Our work also showed that it would have been difficult to identify these enhancer mutations without the unique genetic background of our screen.

In addition, our work generated additional insights into the evolution and function of the LRB E3 ubiquitin-ligases. This work identified a possible role for the LRB and PIF genes in either early embyro development or gamete function. This work also showed that the LRB genes have roles in germination and in ethylene regulation of hypocotyl elongation in the light. Finally, this work showed that LRB homologs likely first appeared in the algal ancestors of land plants.

This work was performed at a primarily-undergraduate university and twelve undergraduate students participated in this research during the course of the grant. Most of these students have gone on to graduate school, medical school, or went on to work in research or clinical laboratories. Two high school students also conducted summer research projects in the lab. Modules involving research questions related to the grant project were included in three different undergraduate laboratory courses at the University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire and collectively involved more than one hundred students.

The grant funded travel to national research conferences for six students and for Dr, Gingerich. Dr. Gingerich's participation in these conferences has led to leadership positions within the American Society of Plant Biologists, most significantly within the newly-formed Primarily Undergraduate Institutions section of the society. This section has provided training and development opportunities for PUI faculty from around the country.
